PLAY.TITLE: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Philo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but this dotage of our Generals
Ore-flowes the measure: those his goodly eyes
That o’re the Files and Musters of the Warre,
Haue glow’d like plated Mars:
Now bend, now turne
The Office and Deuotion of their view
Vpon a Tawny Front. His Captaines heart,
Which in the ſcuffles of great Fights hath burst
The Buckles on his brest, reneages all temper,
And is become the Bellowes and the Fan
To coole a Gypsies Lust.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter Anthony, Cleopatra, her Ladies, the Traine, with Eunuchs fanning her

SPEECH.LINE: Looke where they come:
Take but good note, and you ſhall ſee in him
(The triple Pillar of the world) transform’d
Into a Strumpets Foole. Behold and ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be Loue indeed, tell me how much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: There's beggery in the loue that can be reckon’d

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſet a bourne how farre to be belou’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Then must thou needes finde out new Heauen, new Earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Newes (my good Lord) from Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Grates me, the ſumme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay heare them Anthony.
Fuluia perchance is angry: Or who knowes,
If the ſcarse-bearded Caesar haue not ſent
His powrefull Mandate to you. Do this, or this;
Take in that Kingdome, and Infranchise that:
Perform't, or else we damne thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: How, my Loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Perchance? Nay, and mo’t like:
You must not ſtay heere longer, your dismiſſion
Is come from Caesar, therefore heare it Anthony,
Where's Fuluias Proceſſe? (Caesars I would ſay) both?
Call in the Meſſengers: As I am Egypts Queene,
Thou blushest Anthony, and that blood of thine
Is Caesars homager: else ſo thy cheeke payes ſhame,
When ſhrill-tongu’d Fuluia ſcolds. The Meſſengers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Let Rome in Tyber melt, and the wide Arch
Of the raing’d Empire fall: Heere is my ſpace,
Kingdomes are clay: Our dungie earth alike
Feeds Beast as Man; the Nobleneſſe of life
Is to do thus: when ſuch a mutuall paire,
And ſuch a twaine can doo't, in which I binde
One paine of punishment, the world to weete
We ſtand vp Peereleſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Excellent falshood:
Why did he marry Fuluia, and not loue her?
Ile ſeeme the Foole I am not. Anthony will be himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſtirr’d by Cleopatra.
Now for the loue of Loue, and her ſoft houres,
Let's not confound the time with Conference harsh;
There's not a minute of our liues ſhould ſtretch
Without ſome pleasure now. What ſport to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare the Ambaſſadors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Fye wrangling Queene:
Whom euery thing becomes, to chide, to laugh,
To weepe: who euery paſſion fully ſtriues
To make it ſelfe (in Thee) faire, and admir’d.
No Meſſenger but thine, and all alone, to night
Wee'l wander through the ſtreets, and note
The qualities of people. Come my Queene,
Last night you did desire it. Speake not to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: Is Caesar with Anthonius priz’d ſo ſlight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Philo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſometimes when he is not Anthony,
He comes too ſhort of that great Property
Which ſtill ſhould go with Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: I am full ſorry, that hee approues the common Lyar, who thus ſpeakes of him at Rome; but I will hope of better deeds to morrow. Rest you happy.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Enobarbus, Lamprius, a Southsayer, Rannius, Lucilli-us, Charmian, Iras, Mardian the Eunuch, and Alexas

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: L[ord]. Alexas, ſweet Alexas, mo’t any thing Alexas, almost mo’t absolute Alexas, where's the Soothsayer that you prais’d ſo to'th’ Queene? Oh that I knewe this Husband, which you ſay, must change his Hornes with Garlands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Soothsayer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: Your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the Man? Is't you ſir that know things?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: In Natures infinite booke of Secrecie, a little I can read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Shew him your hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Bring in the Banket quickly: Wine enough,
Cleopatra's health to drinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſir, giue me good Fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: I make not, but foresee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray then, foresee me one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall be yet farre fairer then you are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: He meanes in flesh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: No, you ſhall paint when you are old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Wrinkles forbid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Vex not his prescience, be attentiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Hush.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall be more belouing, then beloued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather heate my Liuer with drinking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, heare him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Good now ſome excellent Fortune: Let mee be married to three Kings in a forenoone, and Widdow them all: Let me haue a Childe at fifty, to whom Herode of Iewry may do Homage. Finde me to marrie me with Octauius Caesar, and companion me with my Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall out-liue the Lady whom you ſerue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh excellent, I loue long life better then Figs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue ſeene and proued a fairer former for-tune, then that which is to approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Then belike my Children ſhall haue no names:
Prythee how many Boyes and Wenches must I haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: If euery of your wishes had a wombe, & fore-tell euery wish, a Million.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Out Foole, I forgiue thee for a Witch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: You thinke none but your ſheets are priuie to your wishes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay come, tell Iras hers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l know all our Fortunes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine, and mo’t of our Fortunes to night, ſhall be drunke to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: There's a Palme presages Chastity, if nothing els.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: E'ne as the o’re-flowing Nylus presageth Fa-mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: Go you wilde Bedfellow, you cannot Soothsay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if an oyly Palme bee not a fruitfull Prog-nostication, I cannot ſcratch mine eare. Prythee tel her but a worky day Fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Fortunes are alike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: But how, but how, giue me particulars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I not an inch of Fortune better then ſhe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better then I: where would you choose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: Not in my Husbands nose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Our worser thoughts Heauens mend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alexas.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, his Fortune, his Fortune. Oh let him mary a woman that cannot go, ſweet Isis, I beseech thee, and let her dye too, and giue him a worse, and let worse follow worse, till the worst of all follow him laughing to his graue, fifty-fold a Cuckold. Good Isis heare me this Prayer, though thou denie me a matter of more waight: good Isis I beseech thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, deere Goddeſſe, heare that prayer of the people. For, as it is a heart-breaking to ſee a handsome man loose-Wiu’d, ſo it is a deadly ſorrow, to beholde a foule Knaue vncuckolded: Therefore deere Isis keep de-corum, and Fortune him accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make mee a Cuckold, they would make themselues Whores, but they'ld doo't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Hush, heere comes Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Not he, the Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Saue you, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: No Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Was he not heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: No Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: He was dispos’d to mirth, but on the ſodaine
A Romane thought hath ſtrooke him.
Enobarbus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Seeke him, and bring him hither: wher's Alexias?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere at your ſeruice.
My Lord approaches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: We will not looke vpon him:
Go with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſen.
SPEECH.LINE: Fuluia thy Wife,
First came into the Field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Against my Brother Lucius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſen.
SPEECH.LINE: I: but ſoone that Warre had end,
And the times ſtate
Made friends of them, ioynting their force 'gainst Caesar,
Whose better iſſue in the warre from Italy,
Vpon the first encounter draue them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what worst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: The Nature of bad newes infects the Teller.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: When it concernes the Foole or Coward: On.
Things that are past, are done, with me. ‘Tis thus,
Who tels me true, though in his Tale lye death,
I heare him as he flatter’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Labienus (this is ſtiffe-newes)
Hath with his Parthian Force
Extended Asia: from Euphrates his conquering
Banner ſhooke, from Syria to Lydia,
And to Ionia, whil'st—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Anthony thou would'st ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake to me home,
Mince not the generall tongue, name
Cleopatra as ſhe is call’d in Rome:
Raile thou in Fuluia's phrase, and taunt my faults
With ſuch full License, as both Truth and Malice
Haue power to vtter. Oh then we bring forth weeds,
When our quicke windes lye ſtill, and our illes told vs
Is as our earing: fare thee well awhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes
SPEECH.LINE: At your Noble pleasure. Exit Meſſenger

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: From Scicion how the newes? Speake there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: The man from Scicion,
Is there ſuch an one?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſtayes vpon your will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him appeare:
These ſtrong Egyptian Fetters I must breake,
Or loose my ſelfe in dotage.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Enter another Meſſenger with a Letter.

SPEECH.LINE: What are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Fuluia thy wife is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Where dyed ſhe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: In Scicion, her length of ſickneſſe,
With what else more ſerious,
Importeth thee to know, this beares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Antho.
SPEECH.LINE: Forbeare me
There's a great Spirit gone, thus did I desire it:
What our contempts doth often hurle from vs,
We wish it ours againe. The present pleasure,
By reuolution lowring, does become
The opposite of it ſelfe: ſhe's good being gon,
The hand could plucke her backe, that ſhou’d her on.
I must from this enchanting Queene breake off,
Ten thousand harmes, more then the illes I know
My idleneſſe doth hatch.
How now Enobarbus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: What's your pleasure, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: I must with haste from hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then we kill all our Women. We ſee how mortall an vnkindneſſe is to them, if they ſuffer our de-parture death's the word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I must be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder a compelling an occasion, let women die. It were pitty to cast them away for nothing, though be-tweene them and a great cause, they ſhould be esteemed nothing. Cleopatra catching but the least noyse of this, dies instantly: I haue ſeene her dye twenty times vppon farre poorer moment: I do think there is mettle in death, which commits ſome louing acte vpon her, ſhe hath ſuch a celerity in dying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: She is cunning past mans thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke Sir no, her paſſions are made of nothing but the finest part of pure Loue. We cannot cal her winds and waters, ſighes and teares: They are greater ſtormes and Tempests then Almanackes can report. This cannot be cunning in her; if it be, ſhe makes a ſhowre of Raine as well as Ioue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I had neuer ſeene her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, you had then left vnseene a wonderfull peece of worke, which not to haue beene blest withall, would haue discredited your Trauaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Fuluia is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Fuluia is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Fuluia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, giue the Gods a thankefull Sacrifice: when it pleaseth their Deities to take the wife of a man from him, it ſhewes to man the Tailors of the earth: com-forting therein, that when olde Robes are worne out, there are members to make new. If there were no more Women but Fuluia, then had you indeede a cut, and the case to be lamented: This greefe is crown’d with Conso-lation, your old Smocke brings foorth a new Petticoate, and indeed the teares liue in an Onion, that ſhould water this ſorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The busineſſe ſhe hath broached in the State,
Cannot endure my absence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: And the busineſſe you haue broach’d heere can-not be without you, especially that of Cleopatra's, which wholly depends on your abode.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: No more light Answeres:
Let our Officers
Haue notice what we purpose. I ſhall breake
The cause of our Expedience to the Queene,
And get her loue to part. For not alone
The death of Fuluia, with more vrgent touches
Do ſtrongly ſpeake to vs: but the Letters too
Of many our contriuing Friends in Rome,
Petition vs at home. Sextus Pompeius
Haue giuen the dare to Caesar, and commands
The Empire of the Sea. Our ſlippery people,
Whose Loue is neuer link’d to the deseruer,
Till his deserts are past, begin to throw
Pompey the great, and all his Dignities
Vpon his Sonne, who high in Name and Power,
Higher then both in Blood and Life, ſtands vp
For the maine Souldier. Whose quality going on,
The ſides o'th’ world may danger. Much is breeding,
Which like the Coursers heire, hath yet but life,
And not a Serpents poyson. Say our pleasure,
To ſuch whose places vnder vs, require
Our quicke remoue from hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall doo't.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Alexas, and Iras.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not ſee him ſince.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: See where he is,
Whose with him, what he does:
I did not ſend you. If you finde him ſad,
Say I am dauncing: if in Myrth, report
That I am ſodaine ſicke. Quicke, and returne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, me thinkes if you did loue him deerly,
You do not hold the method, to enforce
The like from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhould I do, I do not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ch.
SPEECH.LINE: In each thing giue him way, croſſe him in nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou teachest like a foole: the way to lose him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Tempt him not ſo too farre. I wish forbeare,
In time we hate that which we often feare.
But heere comes Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſicke, and ſullen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorry to giue breathing to my purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe me away deere Charmian, I ſhall fall,
It cannot be thus long, the ſides of Nature
Will not ſustaine it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Now my deerest Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you ſtand farther from mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I know by that ſame eye ther's ſome good news.
What ſayes the married woman you may goe?
Would ſhe had neuer giuen you leaue to come.
Let her not ſay ‘tis I that keepe you heere,
I haue no power vpon you: Hers you are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods best know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh neuer was there Queene
So mightily betrayed: yet at the first
I ſaw the Treasons planted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Cleopatra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhould I thinke you can be mine, & true,
(Though you in ſwearing ſhake the Throaned Gods)
Who haue beene false to Fuluia?
Riotous madneſſe,
To be entangled with those mouth-made vowes,
Which breake themselues in ſwearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t ſweet Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay pray you ſeeke no colour for your going,
But bid farewell, and goe:
When you ſued ſtaying,
Then was the time for words: No going then,
Eternity was in our Lippes, and Eyes,
Bliſſe in our browes bent: none our parts ſo poore,
But was a race of Heauen. They are ſo ſtill,
Or thou the greatest Souldier of the world,
Art turn’d the greatest Lyar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had thy inches, thou ſhould'st know
There were a heart in Egypt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me Queene:
The ſtrong neceſſity of Time, commands
Our Seruices a-while: but my full heart
Remaines in vse with you. Our Italy,
Shines o’re with ciuill Swords; Sextus Pompeius
Makes his approaches to the Port of Rome,
Equality of two Domesticke powers,
Breed ſcrupulous faction: The hated growne to ſtrength
Are newly growne to Loue: The condemn’d Pompey,
Rich in his Fathers Honor, creepes apace
Into the hearts of ſuch, as haue not thriued
Vpon the present ſtate, whose Numbers threaten,
And quietneſſe growne ſicke of rest, would purge
By any desperate change: My more particular,
And that which mo’t with you ſhould ſafe my going,
Is Fuluias death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Though age from folly could not giue me freedom
It does from childishneſſe. Can Fuluia dye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: She's dead my Queene.
Looke heere, and at thy Soueraigne leysure read
The Garboyles ſhe awak’d: at the last, best,
See when, and where ſhee died.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: O mo’t false Loue!
Where be the Sacred Violles thou ſhould'st fill
With ſorrowfull water? Now I ſee, I ſee,
In Fuluias death, how mine receiu’d ſhall be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Quarrell no more, but bee prepar’d to know
The purposes I beare: which are, or cease,
As you ſhall giue th’ aduice. By the fire
That quickens Nylus ſlime, I go from hence
Thy Souldier, Seruant, making Peace or Warre,
As thou affects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Cut my Lace, Charmian come,
But let it be, I am quickly ill, and well,
So Anthony loues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: My precious Queene forbeare,
And giue true euidence to his Loue, which ſtands
An honourable Triall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: So Fuluia told me.
I prythee turne aside, and weepe for her,
Then bid adiew to me, and ſay the teares
Belong to Egypt. Good now, play one Scene
Of excellent diſſembling, and let it looke
Like perfect Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: You'l heat my blood no more?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: You can do better yet: but this is meetly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by Sword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: And Target. Still he mends.
But this is not the best. Looke prythee Charmian,
How this Herculean Roman do's become
The carriage of his chafe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile leaue you Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Courteous Lord, one word:
Sir, you and I must part, but that’s not it:
Sir, you and I haue lou’d, but there's not it:
That you know well, ſomething it is I would:
Oh, my Obliuion is a very Anthony,
And I am all forgotten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: But that your Royalty
Holds Idleneſſe your ſubiect, I ſhould take you
For Idleneſſe it ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſweating Labour,
To beare ſuch Idleneſſe ſo neere the heart
As Cleopatra this. But Sir, forgiue me,
Since my becommings kill me, when they do not
Eye well to you. Your Honor calles you hence,
Therefore be deafe to my vnpittied Folly,
And all the Gods go with you. Vpon your Sword
Sit Lawrell victory, and ſmooth ſucceſſe
Be ſtrew’d before your feete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs go. Come: Our ſeparation ſo abides and flies, That thou reciding heere, goes yet with mee; And I hence fleeting, heere remaine with thee. Away.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Octauius reading a Letter, Lepidus, and their Traine

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: You may ſee Lepidus, and henceforth know,
It is not Caesars Naturall vice, to hate
One great Competitor. From Alexandria
This is the newes: He fishes, drinkes, and wastes
The Lampes of night in reuell: Is not more manlike
Then Cleopatra: nor the Queene of Ptolomy
More Womanly then he. Hardly gaue audience
Or vouchsafe to thinke he had Partners. You
Shall finde there a man, who is th’ abstracts of all faults,
That all men follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: I must not thinke
There are, euils enow to darken all his goodneſſe:
His faults in him, ſeeme as the Spots of Heauen,
More fierie by nights Blackneſſe; Hereditarie,
Rather then purchaste: what he cannot change,
Then what he chooses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: You are too indulgent. Let's graunt it is not
Amiſſe to tumble on the bed of Ptolomy,
To giue a Kingdome for a Mirth, to ſit
And keepe the turne of Tipling with a Slaue,
To reele the ſtreets at noone, and ſtand the Buffet
With knaues that ſmels of ſweate: Say this becoms him
(As his composure must be rare indeed,
Whom these things cannot blemish) yet must Anthony
No way excuse his foyles, when we do beare
So great waight in his lightneſſe. If he fill’d
His vacancie with his Voluptuousneſſe,
Full ſurfets, and the drineſſe of his bones,
Call on him for't. But to confound ſuch time,
That drummes him from his ſport, and ſpeakes as lowd
As his owne State, and ours, ‘tis to be chid:
As we rate Boyes, who being mature in knowledge,
Pawne their experience to their present pleasure,
And ſo rebell to iudgement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere's more newes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy biddings haue beene done, & euerie houre
Mo’t Noble Caesar, ſhalt thou haue report
How ‘tis abroad. Pompey is ſtrong at Sea,
And it appeares, he is belou’d of those
That only haue feard Caesar: to the Ports
The discontents repaire, and mens reports
Giue him much wrong’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhould haue knowne no leſſe,
It hath bin taught vs from the primall ſtate
That he which is was wisht, vntill he were:
And the ebb’d man,
Ne're lou’d, till ne're worth loue,
Comes fear’d, by being lack’d. This common bodie,
Like to a Vagabond Flagge vpon the Streame,
Goes too, and backe, lacking the varrying tyde
To rot it ſelfe with motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar I bring thee word,
Menacrates and Menas famous Pyrates
Makes the Sea ſerue them, which they eare and wound
With keeles of euery kinde. Many hot inrodes
They make in Italy, the Borders Maritime
Lacke blood to thinke on't, and flush youth reuolt,
No Veſſell can peepe forth: but ‘tis as ſoone
Taken as ſeene: for Pompeyes name ſtrikes more
Then could his Warre resisted

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Anthony,
Leaue thy lasciuious Vaſſailes. When thou once
Was beaten from Medena, where thou ſlew'st
Hirsius, and Pansa Consuls, at thy heele
Did Famine follow, whom thou fought'st against,
(Though daintily brought vp) with patience more
Then Sauages could ſuffer. Thou did'st drinke
The ſtale of Horses, and the gilded Puddle
Which Beasts would cough at. Thy pallat the[n] did daine
The roughest Berry, on the rudest Hedge.
Yea, like the Stagge, when Snow the Pasture ſheets,
The barkes of Trees thou brows’d. On the Alpes,
It is reported thou did'st eate ſtrange flesh,
Which ſome did dye to looke on: And all this
(It wounds thine Honor that I ſpeake it now)
Was borne ſo like a Soldiour, that thy cheeke
So much as lank’d not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis pitty of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: Let his ſhames quickely
Driue him to Rome, ‘tis time we twaine
Did ſhew our ſelues i'th’ Field, and to that end
Aſſemble me immediate counsell, Pompey
Thriues in our Idleneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: To morrow Caesar,
I ſhall be furnisht to informe you rightly
Both what by Sea and Land I can be able
To front this present time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: Til which encounter, it is my busines too. Farwell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Farwell my Lord, what you ſhal know mean time
Of ſtirres abroad, I ſhall beseech you Sir
To let me be partaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar
SPEECH.LINE: Doubt not ſir, I knew it for my Bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Charmian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, giue me to drinke Mandragora.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: That I might ſleepe out this great gap of time:
My Anthony is away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: You thinke of him too much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: O ‘tis Treason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I trust not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou, Eunuch Mardian?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: What's your Highneſſe pleasure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Not now to heare thee ſing. I take no pleasure
In ought an Eunuch ha's: Tis well for thee,
That being vnseminar’d, thy freer thoughts
May not flye forth of Egypt. Hast thou Affections?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes gracious Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not in deed Madam, for I can do nothing
But what in deede is honeſt to be done:
Yet haue I fierce Affections, and thinke
What Venus did with Mars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Charmion:
Where think'st thou he is now? Stands he, or ſits he?
Or does he walke? Or is he on his Horse?
Oh happy horse to beare the weight of Anthony!
Do brauely Horse, for wot'st thou whom thou moou'st,
The demy Atlas of this Earth, the Arme
And Burganet of men. Hee's ſpeaking now,
Or murmuring, where's my Serpent of old Nyle,
(For ſo he cals me:) Now I feede my ſelfe
With mo’t delicious poyson. Thinke on me
That am with Phœbus amorous pinches blacke,
And wrinkled deepe in time. Broad-fronted Caesar,
When thou was't heere aboue the ground, I was
A morsell for a Monarke: and great Pompey
Would ſtand and make his eyes grow in my brow,
There would he anchor his Aspect, and dye
With looking on his life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Soueraigne of Egypt, haile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: How much vnlike art thou Marke Anthony?
Yet comming from him, that great Med'cine hath
With his Tinct gilded thee.
How goes it with my braue Marke Anthonie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Last thing he did (deere Queene)
He kist the last of many doubled kiſſes
This Orient Pearle. His ſpeech ſtickes in my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine eare must plucke it thence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Friend, quoth he:
Say the firme Roman to great Egypt ſends
This treasure of an Oyster: at whose foote
To mend the petty present, I will peece
Her opulent Throne, with Kingdomes. All the East,
(Say thou) ſhall call her Mistris. So he nodded,
And ſoberly did mount an Arme-gaunt Steede,
Who neigh’d ſo hye, that what I would haue ſpoke,
Was beastly dumbe by him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: What was he ſad, or merry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Like to the time o'th’ yeare, between y extremes
Of hot and cold, he was nor ſad nor merrie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh well diuided disposition: Note him,
Note him good Charmian, ‘tis the man; but note him.
He was not ſad, for he would ſhine on those
That make their lookes by his. He was not merrie,
Which ſeem’d to tell them, his remembrance lay
In Egypt with his ioy, but betweene both.
Oh heauenly mingle! Bee'st thou ſad, or merrie,
The violence of either thee becomes,
So do's it no mans else. Met'st thou my Posts?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam, twenty ſeuerall Meſſengers.
Why do you ſend ſo thicke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's borne that day, when I forget to ſend to Anthonie, ſhall dye a Begger. Inke and paper Char-mian. Welcome my good Alexas. Did I Charmian, e-uer loue Caesar ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh that braue Caesar!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Be choak’d with ſuch another Emphasis,
Say the braue Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: The valiant Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: By Isis, I will giue thee bloody teeth,
If thou with Caesar Paragon againe:
My man of men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: By your mo’t gracious pardon,
I ſing but after you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: My Sallad dayes, When I was greene in iudgement, cold in blood, To ſay, as I ſaide then. But come, away, Get me Inke and Paper, he ſhall haue euery day a ſeuerall greeting, or Ile vnpeo-ple Egypt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Pompey, Menecrates, and Menas, in warlike manner

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: If the great Gods be iust, they ſhall aſſist
The deeds of iustest men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Know worthy Pompey, that what they do de-lay, they not deny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Whiles we are ſutors to their Throne, decayes the thing we ſue for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: We ignorant of our ſelues,
Begge often our owne harmes, which the wise Powres
Deny vs for our good: ſo finde we profit
By loosing of our Prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall do well:
The people loue me, and the Sea is mine;
My powers are Creſſent, and my Auguring hope
Sayes it will come to'th’ full. Marke Anthony
In Egypt ſits at dinner, and will make
No warres without doores. Caesar gets money where
He looses hearts: Lepidus flatters both,
Of both is flatter’d: but he neither loues,
Nor either cares for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar and Lepidus are in the field,
A mighty ſtrength they carry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Where haue you this? ‘Tis false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: From Siluius, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: He dreames: I know they are in Rome together
Looking for Anthony: but all the charmes of Loue,
Salt Cleopatra ſoften thy wand lip,
Let Witchcraft ioyne with Beauty, Lust with both,
Tye vp the Libertine in a field of Feasts,
Keepe his Braine fuming. Epicurean Cookes,
Sharpen with cloyleſſe ſawce his Appetite,
That ſleepe and feeding may prorogue his Honour,
Euen till a Lethied dulneſſe—
How now Varrius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: This is mo’t certaine, that I ſhall deliuer:
Marke Anthony is euery houre in Rome
Expected. Since he went from Egypt, ‘tis
A ſpace for farther Trauaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: I could haue giuen leſſe matter
A better eare. Menas, I did not thinke
This amorous Surfetter would haue donn’d his Helme
For ſuch a petty Warre: His Souldiership
Is twice the other twaine: But let vs reare
The higher our Opinion, that our ſtirring
Can from the lap of Egypts Widdow, plucke
The neere Lust-wearied Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot hope,
Caesar and Anthony ſhall well greet together;
His Wife that’s dead, did trespaſſes to Caesar,
His Brother wan’d vpon him, although I thinke
Not mou’d by Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not Menas,
How leſſer Enmities may giue way to greater,
Were't not that we ſtand vp against them all:
'Twer pregnant they ſhould ſquare between themselues,
For they haue entertained cause enough
To draw their ſwords: but how the feare of vs
May Ciment their diuisions, and binde vp
The petty difference, we yet not know:
Bee't as our Gods will haue't; it onely ſtands
Our liues vpon, to vse our ſtrongest hands
Come Menas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Enobarbus, ‘tis a worthy deed,
And ſhall become you well, to intreat your Captaine
To ſoft and gentle ſpeech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall intreat him
To anſwer like himselfe: if Caesar moue him,
Let Anthony looke ouer Caesars head,
And ſpeake as lowd as Mars. By Iupiter,
Were I the wearer of Anthonio's Beard,
I would not ſhaue't to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis not a time for priuate ſtomacking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Euery time ſerues for the matter that is then borne in't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſmall to greater matters must giue way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Not if the ſmall come first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Your ſpeech is paſſion: but pray you ſtirre
No Embers vp. Heere comes the Noble Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: And yonder Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: If we compose well heere, to Parthia:
Hearke Ventidius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know Mecenas, aske Agrippa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Friends:
That which combin’d vs was mo’t great, and let not
A leaner action rend vs. What's amiſſe,
May it be gently heard. When we debate
Our triuiall difference loud, we do commit
Murther in healing wounds. Then Noble Partners,
The rather for I earnestly beseech,
Touch you the ſowrest points with ſweetest tearmes,
Nor curstneſſe grow to'th’ matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſpoken well:
Were we before our Armies, and to fight,
I ſhould do thus. Flourish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome to Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: Sit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Sit ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I learne, you take things ill, which are not ſo:
Or being, concerne you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: I must be laught at, if or for nothing, or a little, I
Should ſay my ſelfe offended, and with you
Chiefely i'th’ world. More laught at, that I ſhould
Once name you derogately: when to ſound your name
It not concern’d me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: My being in Egypt Caesar, what was't to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: No more then my reciding heere at Rome
Might be to you in Egypt: yet if you there
Did practise on my State, your being in Egypt
Might be my question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: How intend you, practis’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: You may be pleas’d to catch at mine intent,
By what did heere befall me. Your Wife and Brother
Made warres vpon me, and their contestation
Was Theame for you, you were the word of warre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: You do mistake your busines, my Brother neuer
Did vrge me in his Act: I did inquire it.
And haue my Learning from ſome true reports
That drew their ſwords with you, did he not rather
Discredit my authority with yours,
And make the warres alike against my ſtomacke,
Hauing alike your cause. Of this, my Letters
Before did ſatisfie you. If you'l patch a quarrell,
As matter whole you haue to make it with,
It must not be with this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: You praise your ſelfe, by laying defects of iudge-ment to me: but you patcht vp your excuses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo, not ſo:
I know you could not lacke, I am certaine on't,
Very neceſſity of this thought, that I
Your Partner in the cause 'gainst which he fought,
Could not with gracefull eyes attend those Warres
Which fronted mine owne peace. As for my wife,
I would you had her ſpirit, in ſuch another,
The third oth' world is yours, which with a Snaffle,
You may pace easie, but not ſuch a wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enobar.
SPEECH.LINE: Would we had all ſuch wiues, that the men might go to Warres with the women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: So much vncurbable, her Garboiles (Caesar)
Made out of her impatience: which not wanted
Shrodeneſſe of policie to: I greeuing grant,
Did you too much disquiet, for that you must,
But ſay I could not helpe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: I wrote to you, when rioting in Alexandria you
Did pocket vp my Letters: and with taunts
Did gibe my Misiue out of audience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, he fell vpon me, ere admitted, then:
Three Kings I had newly feasted, and did want
Of what I was i'th’ morning: but next day
I told him of my ſelfe, which was as much
As to haue askt him pardon. Let this Fellow
Be nothing of our ſtrife: if we contend
Out of our question wipe him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue broken the Article of your oath, which you ſhall neuer haue tongue to charge me with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: No Lepidus, let him ſpeake,
The Honour is Sacred which he talks on now,
Supposing that I lackt it: but on Caesar,
The Article of my oath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: To lend me Armes, and aide when I requir’d them, the which you both denied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Neglected rather:
And then when poysoned houres had bound me vp
From mine owne knowledge, as neerely as I may,
Ile play the penitent to you. But mine honesty,
Shall not make poore my greatneſſe, nor my power
Worke without it. Truth is, that Fuluia,
To haue me out of Egypt, made Warres heere,
For which my ſelfe, the ignorant motiue, do
So farre aske pardon, as befits mine Honour
To ſtoope in ſuch a case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis Noble ſpoken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mece.
SPEECH.LINE: If it might please you, to enforce no further
The griefes betweene ye: to forget them quite,
Were to remember: that the present neede,
Speakes to attone you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthily ſpoken Mecenas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enobar.
SPEECH.LINE: Or if you borrow one anothers Loue for the instant, you may when you heare no more words of Pompey returne it againe: you ſhall haue time to wrangle in, when you haue nothing else to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Souldier, onely ſpeake no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: That trueth ſhould be ſilent, I had almost for-got.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: You wrong this presence, therefore ſpeake no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too then: your Considerate ſtone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not much dislike the matter, but
The manner of his ſpeech: for't cannot be,
We ſhall remaine in friendship, our conditions
So diffring in their acts. Yet if I knew,
What Hoope ſhould hold vs ſtaunch from edge to edge
Ath' world: I would persue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me leaue Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake Agrippa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast a Sister by the Mothers ſide, admir’d
Octauia: Great Mark Anthony is now a widdower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Say not, ſay Agrippa; if Cleopater heard you, your proofe were well deserued of rashneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not marryed Caesar: let me heere Agrippa further ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: To hold you in perpetuall amitie,
To make you Brothers, and to knit your hearts
With an vn-slipping knot, take Anthony,
Octauia to his wife: whose beauty claimes
No worse a husband then the best of men: whose
Vertue, and whose generall graces, ſpeake
That which none else can vtter. By this marriage,
All little Ielousies which now ſeeme great,
And all great feares, which now import their dangers,
Would then be nothing. Truth's would be tales,
Where now halfe tales be truth's: her loue to both,
Would each to other, and all loues to both
Draw after her. Pardon what I haue ſpoke,
For ‘tis a ſtudied not a present thought,
By duty ruminated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Will Caesar ſpeake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not till he heares how Anthony is toucht,
With what is ſpoke already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: What power is in Agrippa,
If I would ſay Agrippa, be it ſo,
To make this good?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: The power of Caesar,
And his power, vnto Octauia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: May I neuer
(To this good purpose, that ſo fairely ſhewes)
Dreame of impediment: let me haue thy hand
Further this act of Grace: and from this houre,
The heart of Brothers gouerne in our Loues,
And ſway our great Designes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: There's my hand:
A Sister I bequeath you, whom no Brother
Did euer loue ſo deerely. Let her liue
To ioyne our kingdomes, and our hearts, and neuer
Flie off our Loues againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lepi.
SPEECH.LINE: Happily, Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not think to draw my Sword 'gainst Pompey,
For he hath laid ſtrange courtesies, and great
Of late vpon me. I must thanke him onely,
Least my remembrance, ſuffer ill report:
At heele of that, defie him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lepi.
SPEECH.LINE: Time cals vpon's,
Of vs must Pompey presently be ſought,
Or else he ſeekes out vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Where lies he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: About the Mount-Mesena.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: What is his ſtrength by land?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Great, and encreasing:
But by Sea he is an absolute Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: So is the Fame.
Would we had ſpoke together. Hast we for it,
Yet ere we put our ſelues in Armes, dispatch we
The busineſſe we haue talkt of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: With mo’t gladneſſe,
And do inuite you to my Sisters view,
Whether ſtraight Ile lead you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs Lepidus not lacke your companie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Anthony, not ſickeneſſe ſhould detaine me.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Exit omnes. Manet Enobarbus, Agrippa, Mecenas

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mec.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome from Aegypt Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Halfe the heart of Caesar, worthy Mecenas. My honourable Friend Agrippa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Enobarbus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mece.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue cause to be glad, that matters are ſo well disgested: you ſtaid well by't in Egypt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir, we did ſleepe day out of countenaunce: and made the night light with drinking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mece.
SPEECH.LINE: Eight Wilde-Boares rosted whole at a break-fast: and but twelue persons there. Is this true?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: This was but as a Flye by an Eagle: we had much more monstrous matter of Feast, which worthily deser-ued noting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mecenas.
SPEECH.LINE: She's a mo’t triumphant Lady, if report be ſquare to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: When ſhe first met Marke Anthony, ſhe purst vp his heart vpon the Riuer of Sidnis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: There ſhe appear’d indeed: or my reporter de-uis’d well for her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell you,
The Barge ſhe ſat in, like a burnisht Throne
Burnt on the water: the Poope was beaten Gold,
Purple the Sailes: and ſo perfumed that
The Windes were Loue-sicke.
With them the Owers were Siluer,
Which to the tune of Flutes kept ſtroke, and made
The water which they beate, to follow faster;
As amorous of their ſtrokes. For her owne person,
It beggerd all discription, ſhe did lye
In her Pauillion, cloth of Gold, of Tiſſue,
O're-picturing that Venus, where we ſee
The fancie out-worke Nature. On each ſide her,
Stood pretty Dimpled Boyes, like ſmiling Cupids,
With diuers coulour’d Fannes whose winde did ſeeme,
To gloue the delicate cheekes which they did coole,
And what they vndid did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agrip.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh rare for Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Her Gentlewoman, like the Nereides,
So many Mer-maides tended her i'th’ eyes,
And made their bends adornings. At the Helme,
A ſeeming Mer-maide ſteeres: The Silken Tackle,
Swell with the touches of those Flower-soft hands,
That yarely frame the office. From the Barge
A ſtrange inuisible perfume hits the ſense
Of the adiacent Wharfes. The Citty cast
Her people out vpon her: and Anthony
Enthron’d i'th’ Market-place, did ſit alone,
Whisling to'th’ ayre: which but for vacancie,
Had gone to gaze on Cleopater too,
And made a gap in Nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Rare Egiptian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon her landing, Anthony ſent to her,
Inuited her to Supper: ſhe replyed,
It ſhould be better, he became her guest:
Which ſhe entreated, our Courteous Anthony,
Whom nere the word of no woman hard ſpeake,
Being barber’d ten times o’re, goes to the Feast;
And for his ordinary, paies his heart,
For what his eyes eate onely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Royall Wench:
She made great Caesar lay his Sword to bed,
He ploughed her, and ſhe cropt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſaw her once
Hop forty Paces through the publicke ſtreete,
And hauing lost her breath, ſhe ſpoke, and panted,
That ſhe did make defect, perfection,
And breathleſſe powre breath forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mece.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Anthony, must leaue her vtterly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer he will not:
Age cannot wither her, nor custome ſtale
Her infinite variety: other women cloy
The appetites they feede, but ſhe makes hungry,
Where mo’t ſhe ſatisfies. For vildest things
Become themselues in her, that the holy Priests
Bleſſe her, when ſhe is Riggish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mece.
SPEECH.LINE: If Beauty, Wisedome, Modesty, can ſettle
The heart of Anthony: Octauia is
A bleſſed Lottery to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agrip.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs go. Good Enobarbus, make your ſelfe my guest, whilst you abide heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno
SPEECH.LINE: Humbly Sir I thanke you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Anthony, Caesar, Octauia betweene them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: The world, and my great office, will
Sometimes deuide me from your bosome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: All which time, before the Gods my knee ſhall bowe my prayers to them for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Goodnight Sir. My Octauia
Read not my blemishes in the worlds report:
I haue not kept my ſquare, but that to come
Shall all be done byth' Rule: good night deere Lady:
Good night Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar
SPEECH.LINE: Goodnight. Exit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Now ſirrah: you do wish your ſelfe in Egypt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I had neuer come from thence, nor you thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: If you can, your reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee it in my motion: haue it not in my tongue,
But yet hie you to Egypt againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Antho.
SPEECH.LINE: Say to me, whose Fortunes ſhall rise higher
Caesars or mine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: Caesars. Therefore (oh Anthony) ſtay not by his ſide
Thy Daemon that thy ſpirit which keepes thee, is
Noble, Couragious, high vnmatchable,
Where Caesars is not. But neere him, thy Angell
Becomes a feare: as being o’re-powr’d, therefore
Make ſpace enough betweene you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake this no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sooth.
SPEECH.LINE: To none but thee no more but: when to thee,
If thou dost play with him at any game,
Thou art ſure to loose: And of that Naturall lucke,
He beats thee 'gainst the oddes. Thy Luster thickens,
When he ſhines by: I ſay againe, thy ſpirit
Is all affraid to gouerne thee neere him:
But he alway ‘tis Noble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Get thee gone:
Say to Ventigius I would ſpeake with him. Exit.
He ſhall to Parthia, be it Art or hap,
He hath ſpoken true. The very Dice obey him,
And in our ſports my better cunning faints,
Vnder his chance, if we draw lots he ſpeeds,
His Cocks do winne the Battaile, ſtill of mine,
When it is all to naught: and his Quailes euer
Beate mine (in hoopt) at odd's. I will to Egypte:
And though I make this marriage for my peace,
I'th’ East my pleasure lies. Oh come Ventigius.
You must to Parthia, your Commiſſions ready:
Follow me, and reciue't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lepidus.
SPEECH.LINE: Trouble your ſelues no further: pray you hasten your Generals after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agr.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, Marke Anthony, will e'ne but kiſſe Octauia, and weele follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lepi.
SPEECH.LINE: Till I ſhall ſee you in your Souldiers dreſſe,
Which will become you both: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mece.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall: as I conceiue the iourney, be at
Mount before you Lepidus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lepi.
SPEECH.LINE: Your way is ſhorter, my purposes do draw me much about, you'le win two dayes vpon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir good ſucceſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lepi
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cleopater, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me ſome Musicke: Musicke, moody foode of vs that trade in Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SPEECH.LINE: The Musicke, hoa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it alone, let's to Billiards: come Charmian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: My arme is ſore, best play with Mardian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleopa.
SPEECH.LINE: As well a woman with an Eunuch plaide, as with a woman. Come you'le play with me Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mardi.
SPEECH.LINE: As well as I can Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: And when good will is ſhewed,
Though't come to ſhort
The Actor may pleade pardon. Ile none now,
Giue me mine Angle, weele to'th’ Riuer there
My Musicke playing farre off. I will betray
Tawny fine fishes, my bended hooke ſhall pierce
Their ſlimy iawes: and as I draw them vp,
Ile thinke them euery one an Anthony,
And ſay, ah ha; y'are caught.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas merry when you wager’d on your Ang-ling, when your diuer did hang a ſalt fish on his hooke which he with feruencie drew vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: That time? Oh times:
I laught him out of patience: and that night
I laught him into patience, and next morne,
Ere the ninth houre, I drunke him to his bed:
Then put my Tires and Mantles on him, whilst
I wore his Sword Phillippan. Oh from Italie,
Ramme thou thy fruitefull tidings in mine eares,
That long time haue bin barren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Anthonyo's dead.
If thou ſay ſo Villaine, thou kil'st thy Mistris:
But well and free, if thou ſo yeild him.
There is Gold, and heere
My blewest vaines to kiſſe: a hand that Kings
Haue lipt, and trembled kiſſing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: First Madam, he is well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why there's more Gold.
But ſirrah marke, we vse
To ſay, the dead are well: bring it to that,
The Gold I giue thee, will I melt and powr
Downe thy ill vttering throate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Madam heare me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, go too I will:
But there's no goodneſſe in thy face if Anthony
Be free and healthfull; ſo tart a fauour
To trumpet ſuch good tidings. If not well,
Thou ſhouldst come like a Furie crown’d with Snakes,
Not like a formall man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt please you heare me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a mind to ſtrike thee ere thou ſpeak'st:
Yet if thou ſay Anthony liues, ‘tis well,
Or friends with Caesar, or not Captiue to him,
Ile ſet thee in a ſhower of Gold, and haile
Rich Pearles vpon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, he's well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: And Friends with Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Th'art an honeſt man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, and he, are greater Friends then euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Make thee a Fortune from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: But yet Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not like but yet, it does alay
The good precedence, fie vpon but yet,
But yet is as a Iaylor to bring foorth
Some monstrous Malefactor. Prythee Friend,
Powre out the packe of matter to mine eare,
The good and bad together: he's friends with Caesar,
In ſtate of health thou ſaist, and thou ſaist, free.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Free Madam, no: I made no ſuch report,
He's bound vnto Octauia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: For what good turne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: For the best turne i'th’ bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am pale Charmian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, he's married to Octauia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: The mo’t infectious Pestilence vpon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Madam patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you? Strikes him.
Hence horrible Villaine, or Ile ſpurne thine eyes
Like balls before me: Ile vnhaire thy head,

LINE.STAGEDIR: She hales him vp and downe.

SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt be whipt with Wyer, and ſtew’d in brine,
Smarting in lingring pickle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Gratious Madam,
I that do bring the newes, made not the match.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Say ‘tis not ſo, a Prouince I will giue thee,
And make thy Fortunes proud: the blow thou had'st
Shall make thy peace, for mouing me to rage,
And I will boot thee with what guift beside
Thy modestie can begge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: He's married Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo
SPEECH.LINE: Rogue, thou hast liu’d too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then Ile runne:
What meane you Madam, I haue made no fault.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Madam keepe your ſelfe within your ſelfe,
The man is innocent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Some Innocents ſcape not the thunderbolt:
Melt Egypt into Nyle: and kindly creatures
Turne all to Serpents. Call the ſlaue againe,
Though I am mad, I will not byte him: Call?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: He is afeard to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not hurt him,
These hands do lacke Nobility, that they ſtrike
A meaner then my ſelfe: ſince I my ſelfe
Haue giuen my ſelfe the cause. Come hither Sir.
Though it be honeſt, it is neuer good
To bring bad newes: giue to a gratious Meſſage
An host of tongues, but let ill tydings tell
Themselues, when they be felt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue done my duty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he married?
I cannot hate thee worser then I do,
If thou againe ſay yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: He's married Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods confound thee,
Dost thou hold there ſtill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Should I lye Madame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, I would thou didst:
So halfe my Egypt were ſubmerg’d and made
A Cesterne for ſcal’d Snakes. Go get thee hence,
Had'st thou Narciſſus in thy face to me,
Thou would'st appeere mo’t vgly: He is married?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: I craue your Highneſſe pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: He is married?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Take no offence, that I would not offend you,
To punnish me for what you make me do
Seemes much vnequall, he's married to Octauia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh that his fault ſhould make a knaue of thee,
That art not what th’art ſure of. Get thee hence,
The Marchandize which thou hast brought from Rome
Are all too deere for me:
Lye they vpon thy hand, and be vndone by em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Good your Highneſſe patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: In praysing Anthony, I haue disprais’d Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Many times Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am paid for't now: lead me from hence, I faint, oh Iras, Charmian: ‘tis no matter. Go to the Fellow, good Alexas bid him Report the feature of Octauia: her yeares, Her inclination, let him not leaue out The colour of her haire. Bring me word quickly, Let him for euer go, let him not Charmian, Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon, The other wayes a Mars. Bid you Alexas Bring me word, how tall ſhe is: pitty me Charmian, But do not ſpeake to me. Lead me to my Chamber. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter Pompey, at one doore with Drum and Trum-pet: at another Caesar, Lepidus, Anthony, Enobarbus, Me-cenas, Agrippa, Menas with Souldiers Marching

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Hostages I haue, ſo haue you mine:
And we ſhall talke before we fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t meete that first we come to words,
And therefore haue we
Our written purposes before vs ſent,
Which if thou hast considered, let vs know,
If 'twill tye vp thy discontented Sword,
And carry backe to Cicelie much tall youth,
That else must perish heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: To you all three,
The Senators alone of this great world,
Chiefe Factors for the Gods. I do not know,
Wherefore my Father ſhould reuengers want,
Hauing a Sonne and Friends, ſince Iulius Caesar,
Who at Phillippi the good Brutus ghosted,
There ſaw you labouring for him. What was't
That mou’d pale Caſſius to conspire? And what
Made all-honor’d, honeſt, Romaine Brutus,
With the arm’d rest, Courtiers of beautious freedome,
To drench the Capitoll, but that they would
Haue one man but a man, and that his it
Hath made me rigge my Nauie. At whose burthen,
The anger’d Ocean fomes, with which I meant
To ſcourge th’ ingratitude, that despightfull Rome
Cast on my Noble Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Take your time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou can'st not feare vs Pompey with thy ſailes.
Weele ſpeake with thee at Sea. At land thou know'st
How much we do o’re-count thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: At Land indeed
Thou dost orecount me of my Fathers house:
But ſince the Cuckoo buildes not for himselfe,
Remaine in't as thou maist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lepi.
SPEECH.LINE: Be pleas’d to tell vs,
(For this is from the present how you take)
The offers we haue ſent you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: There's the point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Which do not be entreated too,
But waigh what it is worth imbrac’d

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: And what may follow to try a larger Fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue made me offer
Of Cicelie, Sardinia: and I must
Rid all the Sea of Pirats. Then, to ſend
Measures of Wheate to Rome: this greed vpon,
To part with vnhackt edges, and beare backe
Our Targes vndinted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SPEECH.LINE: That's our offer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Know then I came before you heere,
A man prepar’d
To take this offer. But Marke Anthony,
Put me to ſome impatience: though I loose
The praise of it by telling. You must know
When Caesar and your Brother were at blowes,
Your Mother came to Cicelie, and did finde
Her welcome Friendly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue heard it Pompey,
And am well ſtudied for a liberall thanks,
Which I do owe you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me haue your hand:
I did not thinke Sir, to haue met you heere,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The beds i'th’ East are ſoft, and thanks to you,
That cal’d me timelier then my purpose hither:
For I haue gained by't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Since I ſaw you last, ther's a change vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I know not,
What counts harsh Fortune cast's vpon my face,
But in my bosome ſhall ſhe neuer come,
To make my heart her vaſſaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Well met heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope ſo Lepidus, thus we are agreed:
I craue our composion may be written
And ſeal’d betweene vs,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: That's the next to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Weele feast each other, ere we part, and lett's
Draw lots who ſhall begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: That will I Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pompey.
SPEECH.LINE: No Anthony take the lot: but first or last, your fine Egyptian cookerie ſhall haue the fame, I haue heard that Iulius Caesar, grew fat with feasting there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue heard much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue faire meaning Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And faire words to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſo much haue I heard,
And I haue heard Appolodorus carried—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: No more that: he did ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: What I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: A certaine Queene to Caesar in a Matris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: I know thee now, how far'st thou Souldier?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, and well am like to do, for I perceiue
Foure Feasts are toward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſhake thy hand,
I neuer hated thee: I haue ſeene thee fight,
When I haue enuied thy behauiour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I neuer lou’d you much, but I ha' prais’d ye,
When you haue well deseru’d ten times as much,
As I haue ſaid you did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Inioy thy plainneſſe,
It nothing ill becomes thee:
Aboord my Gally, I inuite you all.
Will you leade Lords?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Shew's the way, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom
SPEECH.LINE: Come. Exeunt. Manet Enob. & Menas

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy Father Pompey would ne're haue made this
Treaty. You, and I haue knowne ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: At Sea, I thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue done well by water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: And you by Land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: I will praise any man that will praise me, thogh it cannot be denied what I haue done by Land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor what I haue done by water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes ſome-thing you can deny for your owne ſafety: you haue bin a great Theefe by Sea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: And you by Land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: There I deny my Land ſeruice: but giue mee your hand Menas, if our eyes had authority, heere they might take two Theeues kiſſing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: All mens faces are true, whatsomere their hands are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: But there is neuer a fayre Woman, ha's a true
Face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſlander, they ſteale hearts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: We came hither to fight with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: For my part, I am ſorry it is turn’d to a Drink-ing.
Pompey doth this day laugh away his Fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: If he do, ſure he cannot weep't backe againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'haue ſaid Sir, we look’d not for Marke An-thony heere, pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Caesars Sister is call’d Octauia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: True Sir, ſhe was the wife of Caius Marcellus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhe is now the wife of Marcus Anthonius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray'ye ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Then is Caesar and he, for euer knit together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: If I were bound to Diuine of this vnity, I wold not Prophesie ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke the policy of that purpose, made more in the Marriage, then the loue of the parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke ſo too. But you ſhall finde the band that ſeemes to tye their friendship together, will bee the very ſtrangler of their Amity: Octauia is of a holy, cold, and ſtill conuersation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Who would not haue his wife ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Not he that himselfe is not ſo: which is Marke Anthony: he will to his Egyptian dish againe: then ſhall the ſighes of Octauia blow the fire vp in Caesar, and (as I ſaid before) that which is the ſtrength of their Amity, ſhall proue the immediate Author of their variance. An-thony will vse his affection where it is. Hee married but his occasion heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: And thus it may be. Come Sir, will you aboord?
I haue a health for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall take it ſir: we haue vs’d our Throats in
Egypt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let's away.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Musicke playes. Enter two or three Seruants with a Banket

SPEECH.LINE: Heere they'l be man: ſome o' their Plants are ill rooted already, the least winde i'th’ world wil blow them downe.
Lepidus is high Coulord.
They haue made him drinke Almes drinke.
As they pinch one another by the disposition, hee cries out, no more; reconciles them to his entreatie, and himselfe to'th’ drinke.
But it raises the greater warre betweene him & his discretion.
Why this it is to haue a name in great mens Fel-lowship: I had as liue haue a Reede that will doe me no ſeruice, as a Partizan I could not heaue.
To be call’d into a huge Sphere, and not to be ſeene to moue in't, are the holes where eyes ſhould bee, which pittifully disaster the cheekes.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A Sennet ſounded. Enter Caesar, Anthony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Mecenas, Enobarbus, Menes, with other Captaines

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus do they Sir: they take the flow o'th’ Nyle
By certaine ſcales i'th’ Pyramid: they know
By'th’ height, the lowneſſe, or the meane: If dearth
Or Foizon follow. The higher Nilus ſwels,
The more it promises: as it ebbes, the Seedsman
Vpon the ſlime and Ooze ſcatters his graine,
And ſhortly comes to Haruest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'haue ſtrange Serpents there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: I Lepidus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Serpent of Egypt, is bred now of your mud by the operation of your Sun: ſo is your Crocodile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: They are ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Sit, and ſome Wine: A health to Lepidus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not ſo well as I ſhould be:
But Ile ne're out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Not till you haue ſlept: I feare me you'l bee in till then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay certainly, I haue heard the Ptolomies Pyra-misis are very goodly things: without contradiction I haue heard that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menas.
SPEECH.LINE: Pompey, a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pomp.
SPEECH.LINE: Say in mine eare, what is't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Forsake thy ſeate I do beseech thee Captaine,
And heare me ſpeake a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom
SPEECH.LINE: Forbeare me till anon.
This Wine for Lepidus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: What manner o' thing is your Crocodile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſhap’d ſir like it ſelfe, and it is as broad as it hath bredth; It is iust ſo high as it is, and mooues with it owne organs. It liues by that which nourisheth it, and the Elements once out of it, it Transmigrates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: What colour is it of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Of it owne colour too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis a ſtrange Serpent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſo, and the teares of it are wet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caes.
SPEECH.LINE: Will this description ſatisfie him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: With the Health that Pompey giues him, else he is a very Epicure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pomp.
SPEECH.LINE: Go hang ſir, hang: tell me of that? Away:
Do as I bid you. Where's this Cup I call’d for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: If for the ſake of Merit thou wilt heare mee,
Rise from thy ſtoole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke th’art mad: the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue euer held my cap off to thy Fortunes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast ſeru’d me with much faith: what’s else to ſay? Be iolly Lords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: These Quicke-sands Lepidus,
Keepe off, them for you ſinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou be Lord of all the world?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaist thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou be Lord of the whole world?
That's twice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſhould that be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: But entertaine it, and though thou thinke me poore, I am the man will giue thee all the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Hast thou drunke well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: No Pompey, I haue kept me from the cup,
Thou art if thou dar'st be, the earthly Ioue:
What ere the Ocean pales, or ſkie inclippes,
Is thine, if thou wilt ha't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Shew me which way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: These three World-sharers, these Competitors
Are in thy veſſell. Let me cut the Cable,
And when we are put off, fall to their throates:
All there is thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, this thou ſhouldst haue done,
And not haue ſpoke on't. In me ‘tis villanie,
In thee, 't had bin good ſeruice: thou must know,
‘Tis not my profit that does lead mine Honour:
Mine Honour it, Repent that ere thy tongue,
Hath ſo betraide thine acte. Being done vnknowne,
I ſhould haue found it afterwards well done,
But must condemne it now: desist, and drinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: For this, Ile neuer follow
Thy paul’d Fortunes more,
Who ſeekes and will not take, when once ‘tis offer’d,
Shall neuer finde it more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: This health to Lepidus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Beare him ashore,
Ile pledge it for him Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere's to thee Menas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Enobarbus, welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Fill till the cup be hid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: There's a ſtrong Fellow Menas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: A beares the third part of the world man: ſeest not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: The third part, then he is drunk: would it were all, that it might go on wheeles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Drinke thou: encrease the Reeles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: This is not yet an Alexandrian Feast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: It ripen's, towards it: ſtrike the Veſſells hoa.
Heere's to Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: I could well forbear't, it's monstrous labour when I wash my braine, and it grow fouler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Be a Child o'th’ time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Poſſeſſe it, Ile make anſwer: but I had rather fast from all, foure dayes, then drinke ſo much in one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enob.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha my braue Emperour, ſhall we daunce now the Egyptian Backenals, and celebrate our drinke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's ha't good Souldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let's all take hands,
Till that the conquering Wine hath ſteep't our ſense,
In ſoft and delicate Lethe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: All take hands:
Make battery to our eares with the loud Musicke,
The while, Ile place you, then the Boy ſhall ſing.
The holding euery man ſhall beate as loud,
As his ſtrong ſides can volly.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Musicke Playes. Enobarbus places them hand in hand.

SPEECH.LINE: Come thou Monarch of the Vine,
Plumpie Bacchus, with pinke eyne:
In thy Fattes our Cares be drown’d,
With thy Grapes our haires be Crown’d.
Cup vs till the world go round,
Cup vs till the world go round.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you more?
Pompey goodnight. Good Brother
Let me request you of our grauer busineſſe
Frownes at this leuitie. Gentle Lords let's part,
You ſee we haue burnt our cheekes. Strong Enobarbe
Is weaker then the Wine, and mine owne tongue
Spleet's what it ſpeakes: the wilde disguise hath almost
Antickt vs all. What needs more words? goodnight.
Good Anthony your hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile try you on the ſhore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſhall Sir, giues your hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pom.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Anthony, you haue my Father house.
But what, we are Friends?
Come downe into the Boate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Take heed you fall not Menas: Ile not on ſhore,
No to my Cabin: these Drummes,
These Trumpets, Flutes: what
Let Neptune heare, we bid aloud farewell
To these great Fellowes. Sound and be hang’d, ſound out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Enor.
SPEECH.LINE: Hoo ſaies a there's my Cap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men
SPEECH.LINE: Hoa, Noble Captaine, come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Ventidius as it were in triumph, the dead body of Paco-rus borne before him

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ven.
SPEECH.LINE: Now darting Parthya art thou ſtroke, and now
Pleas’d Fortune does of Marcus Craſſus death
Make me reuenger. Beare the Kings Sonnes body,
Before our Army, thy Pacorus Orades,
Paies this for Marcus Craſſus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Romaine.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Ventidius,
Whil'st yet with Parthian blood thy Sword is warme,
The Fugitiue Parthians follow. Spurre through Media,
Mesapotamia, and the ſhelters, whether
The routed flie. So thy grand Captaine Anthony
Shall ſet thee on triumphant Chariots, and
Put Garlands on thy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ven.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Sillius, Sillius,
I haue done enough. A lower place note well
May make too great an act. For learne this Sillius,
Better to leaue vndone, then by our deed
Acquire too high a Fame, when him we ſerues away.
Caesar and Anthony, haue euer wonne
More in their officer, then person. Soſſius
One of my place in Syria, his Lieutenant,
For quicke accumulation of renowne,
Which he atchiu’d by'th’ minute, lost his fauour.
Who does i'th’ Warres more then his Captaine can,
Becomes his Captaines Captaine: and Ambition
(The Souldiers vertue) rather makes choise of loſſe
Then gaine, which darkens him.
I could do more to do Anthonius good,
But 'twould offend him. And in his offence,
Should my performance perish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast Ventidius that, without the which a Souldier and his Sword graunts ſcarce distinction: thou wilt write to Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ven.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile humbly ſignifie what in his name,
That magicall word of Warre we haue effected,
How with his Banners, and his well paid ranks,
The nere-yet beaten Horse of Parthia,
We haue iaded out o'th’ Field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is he now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ven.
SPEECH.LINE: He purposeth to Athens, whither with what hast
The waight we must conuay with's, will permit:
We ſhall appeare before him. On there, paſſe along.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Agrippa at one doore, Enobarbus at another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: What are the Brothers parted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: They haue dispatcht with Pompey, he is gone,
The other three are Sealing. Octauia weepes
To part from Rome: Caesar is ſad, and Lepidus
Since Pompey's feast, as Menas ſaies, is troubled
With the Greene-Sickneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis a Noble Lepidus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: A very fine one: oh, how he loues Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay but how deerely he adores Mark Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar? why he's the Iupiter of men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What's Anthony, the God of Iupiter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Spake you of Caesar? How, the non-pareill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Anthony, oh thou Arabian Bird!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Would you praise Caesar, ſay Caesar go no further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agr.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed he plied them both with excellent praises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: But he loues Caesar best, yet he loues Anthony:
Hoo, Hearts, Tongues, Figure,
Scribes, Bards, Pœts, cannot
Thinke ſpeake, cast, write, ſing, number: hoo,
His loue to Anthony. But as for Caesar,
Kneele downe, kneele downe, and wonder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Both he loues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: They are his Shards, and he their Beetle, ſo:
This is to horse: Adieu, Noble Agrippa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Fortune worthy Souldier, and farewell.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Caesar, Anthony, Lepidus, and Octauia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Antho.
SPEECH.LINE: No further Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: You take from me a great part of my ſelfe:
Vse me well in't. Sister, proue ſuch a wife
As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest Band
Shall paſſe on thy approofe: mo’t Noble Anthony,
Let not the peece of Vertue which is ſet
Betwixt vs, as the Cyment of our loue
To keepe it builded, be the Ramme to batter
The Fortreſſe of it: for better might we
Haue lou’d without this meane, if on both parts
This be not cherisht.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Make me not offended, in your distrust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall not finde,
Though you be therein curious, the lest cause
For what you ſeeme to feare, ſo the Gods keepe you,
And make the hearts of Romaines ſerue your ends:
We will heere part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell my deerest Sister, fare thee well,
The Elements be kind to thee, and make
Thy ſpirits all of comfort: fare thee well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: My Noble Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: The Aprill's in her eyes, it is Loues ſpring,
And these the ſhowers to bring it on: be cheerfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, looke well to my Husbands house: and—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: What Octauia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile tell you in your eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can
Her heart informe her tongue.
The Swannes downe feather
That ſtands vpon the Swell at the full of Tide:
And neither way inclines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: Will Caesar weepe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agr.
SPEECH.LINE: He ha's a cloud in's face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: He were the worse for that were he a Horse, ſo is he being a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Agri.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Enobarbus:
When Anthony found Iulius Caesar dead,
He cried almost to roaring: And he wept,
When at Phillippi he found Brutus ſlaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eno.
SPEECH.LINE: That year indeed, he was trobled with a rheume,
What willingly he did confound, he wail’d,
Beleeu't till I weepe too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſweet Octauia,
You ſhall heare from me ſtill: the time ſhall not
Out-go my thinking on you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Sir, come,
Ile wrastle with you in my ſtrength of loue,
Looke heere I haue you, thus I let you go,
And giue you to the Gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu, be happy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Let all the number of the Starres giue light
To thy faire way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell. Trumpets ſound. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the Fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Halfe afeard to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too, go too: Come hither Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alex.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Maiestie: Herod of Iury dare not looke vpon you, but when you are well pleas’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: That Herods head, Ile haue: but how? When
Anthony is gone, through whom I might commaund it:
Come thou neere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t gratious Maiestie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
