A benefit in this change: but if you ſeeke
To lay on me a Cruelty, by taking
Anthonies course, you ſhall bereaue your ſelfe
Of my good purposes, and put your children
To that destruction which Ile guard them from,
If thereon you relye. Ile take my leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: And may through all the world: tis yours, & we your Scutcheons, and your ſignes of Conquest ſhall Hang in what place you please. Here my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall aduise me in all for Cleopatra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the breefe: of Money, Plate, & Iewels
I am poſſest of, ‘tis exactly valewed,
Not petty things admitted. Where's Seleucus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seleu.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: This is my Treasurer, let him ſpeake (my Lord)
Vpon his perill, that I haue reseru’d
To my ſelfe nothing. Speake the truth Seleucus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seleu.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I had rather ſeele my lippes,
Then to my perill ſpeake that which is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: What haue I kept backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sel.
SPEECH.LINE: Enough to purchase what you haue made known

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay blush not Cleopatra, I approue
Your Wisedome in the deede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: See Caesar: Oh behold,
How pompe is followed: Mine will now be yours,
And ſhould we ſhift estates, yours would be mine.
The ingratitude of this Seleucus, does
Euen make me wilde. Oh Slaue, of no more trust
Then loue that’s hyr’d? What goest thou backe, y ſhalt
Go backe I warrant thee: but Ile catch thine eyes
Though they had wings. Slaue, Soule-leſſe, Villain, Dog.
O rarely base!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Queene, let vs intreat you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Caesar, what a wounding ſhame is this,
That thou vouchsafing heere to visit me,
Doing the Honour of thy Lordlineſſe
To one ſo meeke, that mine owne Seruant ſhould
Parcell the ſumme of my disgraces, by
Addition of his Enuy. Say (good Caesar)
That I ſome Lady trifles haue reseru’d,
Immoment toyes, things of ſuch Dignitie
As we greet moderne Friends withall, and ſay
Some Nobler token I haue kept apart
For Liuia and Octauia, to induce
Their mediation, must I be vnfolded
With one that I haue bred: The Gods! it ſmites me
Beneath the fall I haue. Prythee go hence,
Or I ſhall ſhew the Cynders of my ſpirits
Through th’ Ashes of my chance: Wer't thou a man,
Thou would'st haue mercy on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Forbeare Seleucus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Be it known, that we the greatest are mis-thoght
For things that others do: and when we fall,
We anſwer others merits, in our name
Are therefore to be pittied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Cleopatra,
Not what you haue reseru’d, nor what acknowledg’d
Put we i'th’ Roll of Conquest: ſtill bee't yours,
Bestow it at your pleasure, and beleeue
Caesars no Merchant, to make prize with you
Of things that Merchants ſold. Therefore be cheer’d,
Make not your thoughts your prisons: No deere Queen,
For we intend ſo to dispose you, as
Your ſelfe ſhall giue vs counsell: Feede, and ſleepe:
Our care and pitty is ſo much vpon you,
That we remaine your Friend, and ſo adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: My Master, and my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo: Adieu.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Exeunt Caesar, and his Traine

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: He words me Gyrles, he words me,
That I ſhould not be Noble to my ſelfe.
But hearke thee Charmian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: Finish good Lady, the bright day is done,
And we are for the darke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Hye thee againe,
I haue ſpoke already, and it is prouided,
Go put it to the haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Where's the Queene?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Behold ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Dolabella.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, as thereto ſworne, by your command
(Which my loue makes Religion to obey)
I tell you this: Caesar through Syria
Intends his iourney, and within three dayes,
You with your Children will he ſend before,
Make your best vse of this. I haue perform’d
Your pleasure, and my promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Dolabella, I ſhall remaine your debter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: I your Seruant:
Adieu good Queene, I must attend on Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, and thankes.
Now Iras, what think'st thou?
Thou, an Egyptian Puppet ſhall be ſhewne
In Rome aswell as I: Mechanicke Slaues
With greazie Aprons, Rules, and Hammers ſhall
Vplift vs to the view. In their thicke breathes,
Ranke of groſſe dyet, ſhall we be enclowded,
And forc’d to drinke their vapour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods forbid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, ‘tis mo’t certaine Iras: ſawcie Lictors
Will catch at vs like Strumpets, and ſcald Rimers
Ballads vs out a Tune. The quicke Comedians
Extemporally will ſtage vs, and present
Our Alexandrian Reuels: Anthony
Shall be brought drunken forth, and I ſhall ſee
Some ſqueaking Cleopatra Boy my greatneſſe
I'th’ posture of a Whore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: O the good Gods!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay that’s certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iras.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile neuer ſee't? for I am ſure mine Nailes
Are ſtronger then mine eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that’s the way to foole their preparation,
And to conquer their mo’t absurd intents.
Now Charmian.
Shew me my Women like a Queene: Go fetch
My best Attyres. I am againe for Cidrus,
To meete Marke Anthony. Sirra Iras, go
(Now Noble Charmian, wee'l dispatch indeede,)
And when thou hast done this chare, Ile giue thee leaue
To play till Doomesday: bring our Crowne, and all.
Wherefore's this noise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gards.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is a rurall Fellow,
That will not be deny’de your Highneſſe presence,
He brings you Figges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo
SPEECH.LINE: Let him come in. Exit Guardsman.
What poore an Instrument
May do a Noble deede: he brings me liberty:
My Resolution's plac’d, and I haue nothing
Of woman in me: Now from head to foote
I am Marble constant: now the fleeting Moone
No Planet is of mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guards.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo
SPEECH.LINE: Auoid, and leaue him.
Hast thou the pretty worme of Nylus there,
That killes and paines not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly I haue him: but I would not be the par-tie that ſhould desire you to touch him, for his byting is immortall: those that doe dye of it, doe ſeldome or ne-uer recouer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Remember'st thou any that haue dyed on't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of them no longer then yesterday, a very honeſt wo-man, but ſomething giuen to lye, as a woman ſhould not do, but in the way of honesty, how ſhe dyed of the by-ting of it, what paine ſhe felt: Truely, ſhe makes a verie good report o'th’ worme: but he that wil beleeue all that they ſay, ſhall neuer be ſaued by halfe that they do: but this is mo’t falliable, the Worme's an odde Worme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Get thee hence, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: I wish you all ioy of the Worme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: You must thinke this (looke you,) that the
Worme will do his kinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke you, the Worme is not to bee trusted, but in the keeping of wise people: for indeede, there is no goodneſſe in the Worme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Take thou no care, it ſhall be heeded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Very good: giue it nothing I pray you, for it is not worth the feeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Will it eate me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: You must not think I am ſo ſimple, but I know the diuell himselfe will not eate a woman: I know, that a woman is a dish for the Gods, if the diuell dreſſe her not. But truly, these ſame whorson diuels doe the Gods great harme in their women: for in euery tenne that they make, the diuels marre fiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, get thee gone, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow
SPEECH.LINE: Yes forsooth: I wish you ioy o'th’ worm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me my Robe, put on my Crowne, I haue
Immortall longings in me. Now no more
The iuyce of Egypts Grape ſhall moyst this lip.
Yare, yare, good Iras; quicke: Me thinkes I heare
Anthony call: I ſee him rowse himselfe
To praise my Noble Act. I heare him mock
The lucke of Caesar, which the Gods giue men
To excuse their after wrath. Husband, I come:
Now to that name, my Courage proue my Title.
I am Fire, and Ayre; my other Elements
I giue to baser life. So, haue you done?
Come then, and take the last warmth of my Lippes.
Farewell kinde Charmian, Iras, long farewell.
Haue I the Aspicke in my lippes? Dost fall?
If thou, and Nature can ſo gently part,
The ſtroke of death is as a Louers pinch,
Which hurts, and is desir’d. Dost thou lye ſtill?
If thus thou vanishest, thou tell'st the world,
It is not worth leaue-taking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Diſſolue thicke clowd, & Raine, that I may ſay
The Gods themselues do weepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: This proues me base:
If ſhe first meete the Curled Anthony,
Hee'l make demand of her, and ſpend that kiſſe
Which is my heauen to haue. Come thou mortal wretch,
With thy ſharpe teeth this knot intrinsicate,
Of life at once vntye: Poore venomous Foole,
Be angry, and dispatch. Oh could'st thou ſpeake,
That I might heare thee call great Caesar Aſſe, vnpolicied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Easterne Starre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace:
Dost thou not ſee my Baby at my breast,
That ſuckes the Nurse asleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: O breake! O breake!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SPEECH.LINE: As ſweet as Balme, as ſoft as Ayre, as gentle.
O Anthony! Nay I will take thee too.
What ſhould I ſtay— Dyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: In this wilde World? So fare thee well:
Now boast thee Death, in thy poſſeſſion lyes
A Laſſe vnparalell’d. Downie Windowes cloze,
And golden Phœbus, neuer be beheld
Of eyes againe ſo Royall: your Crownes away,
Ile mend it, and then play—

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Guard rustling in; and Dolabella.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Guard.
SPEECH.LINE: Where's the Queene?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake ſoftly, wake her not.
Caesar hath ſent

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: Too ſlow a Meſſenger.
Oh come apace, dispatch, I partly feele thee.
Approach hoa,
All's not well: Caesar's beguild.
There's Dolabella ſent from Caesar: call him.
What worke is heere Charmian?
Is this well done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Char.
SPEECH.LINE: It is well done, and fitting for a Princeſſe
Descended of ſo many Royall Kings.
Ah Souldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: How goes it heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Guard.
SPEECH.LINE: All dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, thy thoughts
Touch their effects in this: Thy ſelfe art comming
To ſee perform’d the dreaded Act which thou
So ſought'st to hinder.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Caesar and all his Traine, marching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: A way there, a way for Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, you are too ſure an Augurer:
That you did feare, is done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Brauest at the last,
She leuell’d at our purposes, and being Royall
Tooke her owne way: the manner of their deaths,
I do not ſee them bleede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Who was last with them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Guard.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſimple Countryman, that broght hir Figs:
This was his Basket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Poyson’d then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Guard.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Caesar:
This Charmian liu’d but now, ſhe ſtood and ſpake:
I found her trimming vp the Diadem;
On her dead Mistris tremblingly ſhe ſtood,
And on the ſodaine dropt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Noble weakeneſſe:
If they had ſwallow’d poyson, 'twould appeare
By externall ſwelling: but ſhe lookes like ſleepe,
As ſhe would catch another Anthony
In her ſtrong toyle of Grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere on her brest,
There is a vent of Bloud, and ſomething blowne,
The like is on her Arme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Guard.
SPEECH.LINE: This is an Aspickes traile,
And these Figge-leaues haue ſlime vpon them, ſuch
As th’ Aspicke leaues vpon the Caues of Nyle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caesar.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t probable
That ſo ſhe dyed: for her Physitian tels mee
She hath pursu’de Conclusions infinite
Of easie wayes to dye. Take vp her bed,
And beare her Women from the Monument,
She ſhall be buried by her Anthony.
No Graue vpon the earth ſhall clip in it
A payre ſo famous: high euents as these
Strike those that make them: and their Story is
No leſſe in pitty, then his Glory which
Brought them to be lamented. Our Army ſhall
In ſolemne ſhew, attend this Funerall,
And then to Rome. Come Dolabella, ſee
High Order, in this great Solemnity.
